citation.article-title: Thermodesulforhabdus norvegicus gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel sulfate-reducing bacterium from oil field water.

p.s: Description of Thermodesulforhabdus norvegicus sp. nov.
Thermodesulforhabdus norvegicus (Nor.ve.gi.cus. M.L. masc.adj. norvegicus Norwegian, describing the place of isolation)
Rods, 1 x 2.5 μm, motile with single polar flagellum.
Gram-negative type of cell wall structure.
Strict anaerobe, temperature optimum 60°C with a range between 44 and 74°C pH range 6.1-7.7, optimum 6.9.

With sulfate as electron acceptor, electron donors are acetate, lactate, pyruvate, butyrate, succinate, malate, fumarate, valerate, caproate, heptanoate, octanoate, nonadecanoate, decanoate, tridecanoate, pentadecanoate, palmitate, heptadecanoate, stearate, and ethanol.
Formate, propionate, benzoate, H2+CO2, acetate (1 mM) +H2, butanol, 1-propanol, yeast extract, undecanoate, dodecanoate, tridecanoate, tetradecane, and crude oil are not used as electron donors.
With acetate as electron donor, electron acceptors are sulfate and sulfite.
Nitrate, fumarate, sulfur and thiosulfate are not used.
Habitat: anaerobic, warm oil field water.

Type strain A8444 isolated from North Sea oil field water from a Norwegian oil platform. Thermodesulforhabdus norvegicus is deposited at the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen (DSM 9990).
